qas.question: When did the British Army and Royal Navy withdraw from Halifax?
The Canadian Armed Forces were initially organized under what department?

answers.text: the Department of Militia and Defence

qas.question: When did the unification complete of all the Canadian forces to be called the Canadian Army?
What responsibility remained with a commander-in-chief for North America?
Where was the British Crown-in-Council stationed?
What year was the Royal Canadian Navy formed?
When were land forces referred to as the Army of Canada?
Who initially didn't have military command?
When did the French Army and Royal Navy withdraw from Halifax?
The Canadian Armed Forces were initially disorganized under what department?
When did the unification complete of all the Canadian forces to be called the French Army?

context: <b5_0>The responsibility for military command<b5_0/> remained with <a0_0>the <b9_0>British Crown-in-Council<b9_0/><a0_0/>, with a commander-in-chief for North America stationed at <a1_0><b6_0><b10_0>Halifax<b10_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/> until the final withdrawal of British Army and Royal Navy units from that city in <a2_0><b7_0><b11_0>1906<b11_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/>. Thereafter, the Royal Canadian Navy was formed, and, with the advent of military aviation, the Royal Canadian Air Force. These forces were organised under <a3_0>the <b12_0>Department of Militia and Defence<b12_0/><a3_0/>, and split into the Permanent and Non-Permanent Active Militias—frequently shortened to simply The Militia. By 1923, the department was merged into the Department of National Defence, but land forces in Canada were not referred to as the Canadian Army until <a4_0><b8_0><b13_0>November 1940<b13_0/><b8_0/><a4_0/>.
